part.narration: The digital camera begins rolling. At the lens' side, Madame Soleil. At the viewfinder's side, a journalist. The sun's rise begins, casting an orange glow through the studio windows. The journalist speaks.
part.line: Welcome to Game Radar-Escapist-Spot-Sutra's exclusive interview with...
Yuki Soleil-Takeshi.
It's been very hard to get a hold of you since E3.
What have you been up to?

choice.line: Drama, drama, drama.
The game industry is an unruly beast.
Action, action, action!
Anything interesting lately has happened outside of work.

part.narration: Zoom in extremely close to the table.Bang. On the table. Before Yuki's Eyes is NoLifeQueen. NoLifeQueen continues to bang on the table. Soleil pivots to her.
part.line: Get out of here!
Excuse me?
Sorry, I get a bit nervous around people.
part.narration: NoLifeQueen snickers and gets behind the journalist and makes bunny ears and funny faces. The journalist stops the recording.
part.line: Another mouth-shy game developer.
Are you autistic?
Avoidant!
No, no — I'm just a loser.
part.narration: NoLifeQueen claws at her ears and winces and shrieks. Soleil smiles. The journalist presses the tape recorder button.
part.line: Sega's work under your direction has been nothing short of unique.
What do you attribute most to the team's influence on games?

choice.line: Diversity.
The PNN's employees are a wide range of peoples with a wide range of experiences.
They all come together with each of their uniquely-lived lives.
Life experience spawns great simulation.
Necessity.
The PNN's employees all have needs.
We — and only we — are in a recession.
We — and only we — stare stark in the face of bankruptcy.
choice.narration: NoLifeQueen laughs and rubs the journalist's shoulders.

part.line: Why the insistence on "Madame?"

choice.line: I'm married.
My wife and I are in a very healthy relationship.
No legal acknowledgement, but we need no such confirmation.
Bond is bond, right?
I own a brothel.
"Video games, at their best, are like prostitutes."

part.line: Do you like making video games?
Do you deeply, truly enjoy being within the current bounds of the medium?

choice.line: Yes.
Simulation is the highest medium.
It is limited only by our own mental capacity —
and, sadly, our own mental capacity is all we will have.
No.
choice.narration: NoLifeQueen throws her hat on the ground and stomps on it.
choice.line: There are greater things than video games.
Game designers are gods, but only to their own worlds.
Who wants to be master of a world that belongs to man?

part.narration: The journalist switches the camera from recording-mode to still-mode. He raises from his chair. So does Soleil. NoLifeQueen watches intently. The journalist smiles.
part.line: It's so nice to have an interview that's actually personal.
Everyone I've ever interviewed seemed... corporate.
But whatever little you answered, it was raw. It was real.
Please — get in front of something. Strike a pose.
part.narration: Madame Soleil gets in front of something.Player get in front of something, Main Action is pose. Madame Soleil strikes a pose. NoLifeQueen wraps her arm around the shoulder of Soleil.
part.line: I will pull every string — push every button — get on every nerve,
To get not a character, not a product, but you — a person — on the magazine cover.
Smile on, Madame Soleil.
Please — call me Yuki.
part.narration: Time-lapse zoom out. In the next review, Yuki's face will appear on a magazine.The journalist packs his things. The journalist leaves. Yuki stands in place, wide grin, lids lightly fastened. NoLifeQueen dances around her, dances among her, tries to dance with her — no avail. NoLifeQueen leaves. Allies, comrades, friends and family fill the studio. Nine o'clock.
